examples.en: I can’t agree with this price. It's like a freebie.
examples.ja: その価には同意できないな。タダ同然じゃないか。

examples.en: No, no, no, this is a watch worth 5 million yen, okay?
examples.ja: いやいや、これ、五百万円の価が付いている時計だよ？

examples.en: The view from here in the spring when the cherry blossoms are in full bloom is truly priceless.
examples.ja: 春に桜が満開になった時のここからの眺めは、まさに価千金です。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

価 refers to the monetary value or the price of goods in a transaction. Although it's somewhat old-fashioned and less common these days, you may still see it used in advanced phrases like 価をつける (to set a price) or 一文の価もない (not even worth a penny).

Note that あたい can also refer to a numerical value in mathematics, such as the value a variable or function takes, but it's more commonly written with the kanji 値 in this use.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Okay, this is a great <vocabulary>value</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>price</vocabulary>. Wait, what is? <reading>A tie</reading> (あたい). Get a tie, and it will make you more professional which will help you to get a better job. Great value, right there, just for a tie.

examples.en: Do you know how much the value of money has changed since then?
examples.ja: その時からどれぐらい貨幣価値が変わったか、知っているかい？

meaning_mnemonic: 貨幣 is "<kanji>currency</kanji>" and 価値 is "<kanji>value</kanji>." This shows the <vocabulary>currency value</vocabulary>. Hopefully it's good for you when you visit Japan!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Immersed</kanji> to the point where it's <kanji>transparent</kanji>, because it's so soaked... that is total <vocabulary>permeation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>soaking</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>osmosis</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Candidate Koichi was provokingly cool before the presidential debate.

meaning_mnemonic: If 憎む means "to hate" then this adjective version is <vocabulary>hateful</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Who on earth is the lady holding the violet folding fan?
examples.ja: あの、紫色の扇をもったご婦人は一体どなたですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic for you: 

You're most likely to need a <vocabulary>folding fan</vocabulary> in <reading>Auggie</reading> (おうぎ), AKA August, since that's usually when it's hottest in a lot of places. Just keep in mind that a folding fan = Auggie accessory, and hopefully the おうぎ reading will stick to you (just like the August humidity… unless you have an 扇 on hand.)

examples.en: Our fans have the same design, but mine seems to be a little smaller and lighter than yours.
examples.ja: 同じ模様の団扇だけど、私の物の方があなたのより少し小さくて軽いみたいね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>group</kanji> of <kanji>folding fan</kanji>s, no matter how big it gets, is still a <vocabulary>fan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 団 is an exceptional reading. It's the same as 内's reading so you can think about how a group of folding fans to make a big fan is just a bunch of fans inside of fans.

The reading for 扇 is also an exceptional reading. Imagine a <reading>wa</reading>lrus (わ) using the 内 fan.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> is the color spectrum that's outside purple. Those are <vocabulary>ultraviolet rays</vocabulary> (the lines are the rays).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the on’yomi reading of the 紫 kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Do you know what animal has the best protection from <vocabulary>ultraviolet rays</vocabulary>? <reading>Shee</reading>p (し), obviously. The thick fur of wool is the best UV protection. I mean, you've never seen sheep tanned and sunburned, right?

examples.en: Her review was kind of abstract, so I didn’t really understand it.

抽出 is commonly used to refer to the extraction of substances, such as extracting juice, essences, or compounds from materials like chemicals or metals. Depending on the context, it could also refer to <vocabulary>extracting</vocabulary> relevant information from a dataset or text.

examples.en: When I was saying my wedding vows I knew I was marrying the wrong man.

You swore an <vocabulary>oath</vocabulary> to her, pledging loyalty, support and companionship. Try to picture a chica you would exchange vows with. In fact, it doesn't have to be romantic. Maybe you both just vowed to read more books this year.

examples.en: When the hunchbacked old lady was sent to a detention center for being an illegal immigrant, she realized that it would be where she met her death.
examples.ja: 背中の曲がったお婆さんは、不法滞在者として拘置所に拘留された時、そこで自分が死を迎えることになることを悟りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>realize</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary>. But you probably already realized that…

悟る is often used when someone understands something deeply, not just at the surface-level. It's a sudden, clear realization. So this also means <vocabulary>to attain enlightenment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You just realized something so amazing that you can't believe it. That realization, wow! You were able <vocabulary>to realize</vocabulary> something so big that you <reading>sat</reading> (さと) down in disbelief. If you didn't you would have fallen on the ground.

examples.en: I resigned myself to undergo weight loss surgery.
examples.ja: 私は痩身手術を受ける覚悟を決めました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>awake</kanji> and <kanji>realize</kanji> something, you've achieved <vocabulary>mental readiness</vocabulary>. You have the <vocabulary>resolution</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>determination</vocabulary> to face any challenge now.

覚悟 refers to mentally preparing yourself to face a difficult situation or accept an unfavorable outcome. It conveys a sense of strong determination and readiness to confront risks.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Open</kanji> up <kanji>cultivation</kanji> back on this land. It was closed before, due to it being a wasteland, but now it's time for <vocabulary>reclamation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cultivation</vocabulary> of this land.

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>prune</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to prune</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to mow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to cut</vocabulary>).

examples.en: I am really sorry for being a jerk yesterday. I’ll mow the grass today to apologize.

reading_mnemonic: The reading is 草 and 刈 put together into one. The か reading for 刈り comes from the kanji's reading.

examples.en: My parents are farmers who raise rice so I have to help them harvest rice this weekend.

examples.en: He looks like a strong warrior of long ago, but he wailed when I accidentally pressed a blister on his foot.

meaning_mnemonic: When you are <kanji>sturdy</kanji> and <kanji>healthy</kanji> you are full of <vocabulary>vigor</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>virility</vocabulary>.

examples.en: She is not my mother, she’s just a chaperone.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>solely</kanji>, and this means <vocabulary>solely</vocabulary>, but also other related things like <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>merely</vocabulary>. They're all pretty close, so try to remember a few!
reading_mnemonic: To spice up something you'd describe with words like <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>simply</vocabulary>, use "<reading>ta-da</reading> (ただ)" to spice it up. It's like magic! Now it isn't just a gift, it's a TA-DA surprise gift.

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>solely</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji>. The <vocabulary>only</vocabulary> one. The <vocabulary>sole</vocabulary> one. Totally <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 唯 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, though there is also a shortened version which has ゆい shortened to ゆ. The reading for 一 is the one you learned with 統一, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: I can’t even explain materialism in my native language, so how can I explain it in a foreign language?

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>watered</kanji>. When something is watered it becomes moist, right? That's why this verb is <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moistened</vocabulary>.

潤う refers to things being well-moisturized, like skin or eyes. Think of them as being enriched with moisture. That's why the meaning also extends to financial prosperity — moisture enriches the body, and financial gain enriches your life or business. So this word also means <vocabulary>to be prosperous</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Companies with very rough work environments are often called "black companies" in Japan.
examples.ja: 劣悪な職場環境の会社は、日本ではしばしば「ブラック企業」と呼ばれます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Inferiority</kanji> is <kanji>bad</kanji>. It is <vocabulary>inferiority</vocabulary>, after all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That con artist was a mass of inferiority complexes.
examples.ja: その詐欺師は劣等感の塊だった。

examples.en: I tend to compare myself with others and feel inferior to them.
examples.ja: 人と自分を比べては、劣等感に苛まれてしまう。

examples.en: I was under the false impression that she had an inferiority complex towards me.
examples.ja: 彼女が私に対して劣等感を抱いていると誤解していました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Inferiority</kanji> is what I feel because I don't have an <kanji>equal</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji> with you. This is due to my <vocabulary>inferiority complex</vocabulary>, my <vocabulary>sense of inferiority </vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He hates me now, so I’m pretty sure that I'm even more inferior to him than a nodding acquaintance.
examples.ja: 今、彼は私のこと嫌っているから、私の立場は挨拶程度の人よりも劣っているってのははっきりしてるわ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>inferiority</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be inferior to</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When thinking about cars, an <reading>auto</reading>matic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

examples.en: Having sharp intuition is the key to success.
examples.ja: 成功の秘訣は、鋭い勘をもつことです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also could mean <vocabulary>perception</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hunch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned from the kanji.

examples.en: Taking various circumstances into consideration, quitting the job was the best option for me.
examples.ja: 様々な状況を勘案すると、私にとって仕事を辞めることがベストな選択だったんです。

examples.en: I try to take into consideration how I would feel if things were said or done to me.
examples.ja: 自分がされたり言われたりしたらどう思うかってことも勘案に入れるようにしてます。

examples.en: What kinds of risks have you taken into consideration concerning this investment?
examples.ja: この投資に関して、どのようなリスクを勘案していますか。

meaning_mnemonic: Using our <kanji>intuition</kanji> we will come up with a <kanji>plan</kanji>. We'll be <vocabulary>taking into consideration</vocabulary> the information we have along with our intuition, so don't worry.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Cut me some slack. It’s been a long day and I’m terribly tired.
examples.ja: 勘弁してよ。今日は忙しかったし、滅茶苦茶疲れているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Intuition</kanji> from my <kanji>dialect</kanji> tells me that I should <vocabulary>pardon</vocabulary> you. Give you <vocabulary>forgiveness</vocabulary>. You're lucky I speak this dialect.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can’t drink because I get drunk easily, so it would be nice if we didn’t split the alcohol bill.
examples.ja: 私は下戸でお酒を飲まないので、お酒のお勘定は割り勘じゃない方が嬉しいんですが。

meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>divide</kanji> the <kanji>intuition</kanji> up. For some reason when I say "intuition" I mean "money" because this is referring to <vocabulary>splitting the cost</vocabulary>, like when you're at a restaurant.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 割る and 勘, put together.

examples.en: "Excuse me, my mistake. I thought you were someone else." "Exactly who did you mistake me for? Please. Tell me."
examples.ja: 「すみません、間違えました。違う人と 勘違いしました。」「正確には誰と間違えたんですか？お願いします。教えてください。」

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>intuition</kanji> <kanji>difference</kanji> is a <vocabulary>misunderstanding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wrong guess</vocabulary>. Sorry! My intuition was off.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This is the queen's necklace.
examples.ja: これは王妃の首飾りです。

examples.en: The person in that car was the queen.
examples.ja: その車に乗っていたのは王妃でした。

examples.en: The third-ranked queen consort was secretly fed up with the principal queen consort.
examples.ja: 第三王妃は、内心では第一王妃にうんざりしていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
When a <kanji>king</kanji> takes a <kanji>royal consort</kanji>, she becomes the <vocabulary>queen</vocabulary>.

王妃 is a word for the wife of a reigning king. She's a queen because of who she married, not because she has any power herself. The more technical term for that is <vocabulary>queen consort</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There ain't no way the Crown Princess would volunteer for the army.
examples.ja: 皇太子妃が軍に志願するはずねぇだろうが。

examples.en: The Crown Princess's words had the mysterious power to end quarrels.
examples.ja: 皇太子妃の言葉は、争いを収める不思議な力を持っていた。

examples.en: The Crown Princess read books until late each night to learn the customs of the new land.
examples.ja: 皇太子妃は新しい国の風習を学ぶため、毎夜遅くまで書を読んだ。

examples.en: The Crown Princess wordlessly saw the Crown Prince off as he left on campaign.
examples.ja: 皇太子妃は遠征に出る皇太子の背を、言葉なく見送った。

examples.en: The Crown Princess' final words are still spoken of as a palace mystery.
examples.ja: 皇太子妃が最後に残した言葉は、今も宮廷の謎として語られている。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 皇太子 is "crown prince"? Well, when a crown prince gets married his royal consort is the <vocabulary>crown princess</vocabulary>.

皇太子妃 specifically refers to the wife of the Crown Prince, rather than a woman who is the heir to the throne herself. Technically speaking, she is a <vocabulary>crown princess consort</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Fugu bumped into Princess Salmon on purpose.
examples.ja: フグは、わざとサーモン妃にぶつかりました。

examples.en: Prince William and Princess Catherine enjoyed seasonal flowers as they walked in the garden.
examples.ja: ウィリアム王子とキャサリン妃は、庭を散歩しながら季節の花を楽しみました。

examples.en: Princess Kanae really valued interacting with children.
examples.ja: カナエ妃は子どもたちとの交流をとても大切にしていました。

examples.en: Before the accession, Queen Camilla was referred to in Japanese as "Princess Camilla" or "Lady Camilla."
examples.ja: カミラ王妃は、即位前は日本語で「カミラ妃」や「カミラ夫人」と呼ばれました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>royal consort</kanji>, so adding it to someone's name gives you their royal style: "<vocabulary>Princess</vocabulary> ______," or, in some cases, "<vocabulary>Queen</vocabulary> ______."

〜妃 essentially refers to the wife of a crown prince, emperor, or other royal family member. These days, you'll almost always see it used with princesses, like ダイアナ妃 (Princess Diana) or キャサリン妃 (Princess Catherine), but in historical contexts you'll occasionally see it used with queen consorts and empress consorts too.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I asked for an appointment, but he wouldn’t give me the time of day because he apparently has a some kind of grudge against the president of our company.
examples.ja: アポを取ろうとしたんだけど、彼はどうやらうちの社長に何か恨みがあるみたいで、時間をくれなかったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: 恨む is "to hold a grudge." This is the noun version, which is a <vocabulary>grudge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>resentment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 恨む, so if you know that no need to hold a grudge.

examples.en: I heard her grandmother grumble, "That girl’s shyness should be pitied."
examples.ja: 彼女のお婆さんが、「あの子の人見知りは哀れむべきものだ」とぼやくのを聞きました。

meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>pathetic</kanji> then you should try <vocabulary>to pity</vocabulary> that thing.
reading_mnemonic: <reading>Awww</reading> (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.

examples.en: I want to make my restaurant a place of rest and relaxation for busy salarymen.
examples.ja: 私はうちの食堂を忙しいサラリーマンの憩いの場にしたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If 憩う is to rest, then this noun version (I know it looks like an adjective, but it's not) would be <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 憩う, so if you know that you can rest easy.

examples.en: I thought you are a big spender, and you turned out to be a con artist.
examples.ja: 派手にお金を使っているなぁと思っていたら、詐欺師だったんですね！

examples.en: I heard that there are quite a few real estate scammers out there.
examples.ja: 不動産詐欺師というものが結構いるらしい。

examples.en: "Hey, did you just call me a liar?" "No, but I called you a swindler."
examples.ja: 「ねぇ、今俺のこと、嘘つきって言った？」「そうは言ってないけど、詐欺師とは言ったよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 詐欺 is "fraud." An <kanji>expert</kanji> in fraud is someone who does this it lot, and possibly for a living. That's a <vocabulary>swindler</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>con artist</vocabulary>,  or a <vocabulary>scammer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 詐欺 as well.

examples.en: I’ve always dreamed of experiencing the red-light district.
examples.ja: 花柳界を経験してみるのが夢だったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>red light district</kanji> (花柳) <kanji>world</kanji> of the red light district is the <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>, though this can refer especially to the "<vocabulary>pleasure quarters</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>world of the geisha</vocabulary>" as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The man they arrested is suspected of breaking into the rest area.
examples.ja: 逮捕された男は、休憩所に不法侵入した疑いがかけられていた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rest</kanji> (休憩) <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rest area</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rest stop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Please don't rush—just drive safely.
examples.ja: 慌てないで、安全運転をお願いします。

examples.en: I panicked, thinking there was a fire, and threw some water, but it was just a candle.
examples.ja: 火事だと思い、慌てて水をかけたら、ただのロウソクだった。

examples.en: Don't hurry, do it carefully.
examples.ja: 慌てず、慎重にね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>confused</kanji> or <kanji>bewildered</kanji> but this is usually just used when someone starts <vocabulary>to panic</vocabulary>. They're so confused and bewildered that they try <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary> through things.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you start <vocabulary>to panic</vocabulary> you can't help but blurt out, "<reading>A wha-</reading> (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.

examples.en: The village was consumed with panic on the day I wasn't there.
examples.ja: 私が留守だった日、村は恐慌に包まれた。

examples.en: I wasn't expecting to experience two economic scares in my lifetime.
examples.ja: 人生で二度もの経済恐慌を経験するとは思っていなかったよ。

examples.en: The entire country flew into a panic.
examples.ja: 国全体が恐慌状態に陥った。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Fear</kanji> mixed with <kanji>confusion</kanji> creates <vocabulary>panic</vocabulary>! You get a <vocabulary>scare</vocabulary> so bad, you're fearful and you don't know what to do.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: Which leg did you kick with?
examples.ja: どっちの足で蹴ったの？

examples.en: Why did you reject the offer?
examples.ja: どうしてそのオファーを蹴っちゃったの？

examples.en: I saw a yokai kick a fairy.
examples.ja: 妖怪が妖精を蹴ったのを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>kick</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to kick</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

examples.en: I confessed my love to Koichi, but he totally rejected me.
examples.ja: コウイチに告白したが一蹴された。

examples.en: Viet beat the yokai easily.
examples.ja: ビエトは妖怪を一蹴した。

examples.en: I submitted a holiday request to my boss but it was flatly rejected.
examples.ja: 上司に休暇を申請したが一蹴された。

meaning_mnemonic: Giving <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>kick</kanji> is certainly an effective (if brutal) way <vocabulary>to flatly reject</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to brush aside</vocabulary> something or someone. That one kick can also be used <vocabulary>to easily beat</vocabulary> anyone.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.  First up, notice that <reading>いち</reading> changes to <reading>いっ</reading>. And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji <kanji>蹴</kanji> (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you're planning <vocabulary>to flatly reject</vocabulary> someone, one <kanji>kick</kanji> is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう) on first.

examples.en: Is the rice done cooking?
examples.ja: ご飯、炊けた？

examples.en: Today's dinner is curry spaghetti, not curry rice. I forgot to put the plug in, so the rice isn't cooked.
examples.ja: 今晩はカレーライスじゃなくてカレースパゲッティ。コンセントを差し忘れて、ご飯が炊けてなかったんだ。

examples.en: It's only five minutes left until the daikon gets cooked.
examples.ja: 大根が炊けるまであと五分やで。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be boiled</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be done cooking</vocabulary>. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.

examples.en: Suddenly, the window shattered into tiny pieces.
examples.ja: 急に窓ガラスが粉々に砕けた。

examples.en: I like sitting on the beach and watching the waves break on the shore..
examples.ja: 海辺に座って、波が砕けるのを見るのが好きです。

examples.en: When I felt like the tension in the air finally broke, the party was almost over.
examples.ja: 緊張した雰囲気がやっと砕けたと思ったんだけど、パーティはすぐに終わっちゃったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to be smashed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be shattered</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary> (for things like waves and tension!).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 砕く.

examples.en: I work as an associate professor at Kyoto University.
examples.ja: 私は京都大学で准教授として務めています。

examples.en: I believe Asano-sensei is an associate professor.
examples.ja: 確か、浅野先生は准教授のはずです。

examples.en: This is Dr. Kimura, who will be assuming the position of specially appointed associate professor at this center soon.
examples.ja: こちらは、今度このセンターの特任准教授に着任される木村博士です。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 教授 meaning "professor"? That makes this a <kanji>semi</kanji> professor, or in other words, an <vocabulary>associate professor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
